data.title: Bug: misleading message when selecting deleted images in the Git pane
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4
- OS Version: macOS El Capitan

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open any project/folder bounded to Git and containing an image
2. Delete an image (tested with .png)
3. Open the Git pane and select the entry for the deleted image

Observed:
The following message is shown: **ERROR**: Unable to open 'xxx.png (HEAD)': File seems to be binary and cannot be opened as text. The image is not shown.

Expected:
The image shall be shown without an error message, as it happens with [deleted] text files.

data.title: Get TextDocument silently.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

I'm developing an extension that read the _content_ and get the _languageId_ of files in the project. To do that, I use this API to get a TextDocument object:

``` typescript
workspace.openTextDocument(uri)
```

However, as I see, this also triggers other extensions related to the file (e.g. linters). 
Is there any way to get a TextDocument object (i.e. file content + languageId) only?

data.title: Expose more information about the state of the integrated terminal internally within vscode and to the API

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: Originally discussed in #9957 and then in #11214, consumers of the API want to know more about the process(es) currently being run within the terminal, such as what process(es) are running and whether the terminal is "busy".

data.title: Option to show folder name in tabs for files with the same name
data.body:
When several files with the same name are opened (which is especially common with index files), it would be great to have the option to show the folder name of its location. An option between showing the folder name or a path could cover different use cases.

This is how Sublime does it:
![sublime_tabs_folder_names](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1992115/18186458/e7c1fcae-7070-11e6-86c9-00ce660b0721.png)

data.title: Vscode coloring is broken for large files
data.body:
This issue was moved. Not sure how to reopen:
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/10901

This should be a vscode issue, not an extension issue. The extension doesn't control colorization.

data.title: Fix Terminal.show preserveFocus parameter
data.body:
Fixes #11325 

---

Verified that all calls into `setActiveTerminal` come from a `TerminalService.show(focus: boolean)` call which require an explicit indicator so this minimal change should be fine. Manually verified the following cases:
- API
  - Creating terminal via API (focus)
  - Hide terminal then `show(false)` via API (focus)
  - Hide terminal then `show(true)` via API (no focus)
  - Hide terminal then `show(true)` (no focus) then `show(false)` (focus)
- Regular commands
  - Create first terminal (focus)
  - Create second terminal (focus)
  - Focus next/previous terminal (focus)

data.title: Fix terminal exception when create new is called on uninitialized panel
data.body: Fixes #11377

data.title: Make errors descriptions more visually clear
data.body:
You've all heard about syntax coloring it is something to make it easier for kinder-gardeners to do programming.

See it is quite hard to distinguish logical/context parts of the message and identify the problems from such output:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/736697/18182803/eabcf0e6-70aa-11e6-88e6-7febacf0d419.png)

It would be good if error descriptions contained some highlighting of important parts like particular error messages (underlined on the picture), and maybe included code/signature highlighting as well.

data.title: MAC Intellisence "Tab" keypress not selecting highlighted item (inserts regular Tab instead)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: **1.4.0**
- OS Version: **MAC 10.10.3**

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Type in something that brings up intellisence, for example `doc` (which will bring up an intellisence dropdown with `document` being at the top and selected)
2. Press the `TAB` Key. Instead of selecting document, it will just create a tab in your document. Now you have `doc(tab-spaces-here)`(several spaces after doc)

On windows the Tab key selects the item you have highlighted in intellisense.

Just wanted to point it out, loving VSCode otherwise 👍 👍

data.title: [json] JSON Schema intellisense markdown/jsdoc not parsing links anymore
data.body:
- VSCode Version:
  Version 1.4.0 (1.4.0)
- OS Version:
  Mac OSX 10.11.5
## Before (not sure what version, a few months ago)

![screenshot 2016-09-01 15 12 44](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/317498/18181057/78a2795c-7057-11e6-9680-86dbbc662b75.png)

✅  Clickthrough possible
## Now

![screenshot 2016-09-01 15 12 24](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/317498/18181075/87382e94-7057-11e6-9575-500671e62d7e.png)

❌  Clickthrough **not** possible
## Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=sequoia.loopback-json-schemas
2. Create a file called `common/models/test.json`
3. add opening curly brace `{`
4. Mouse over
- **Expected**: link is rendered & you can click through to the browser
- **Actual**: link **not** rendered, click through not possible.
## Additional note

This is a jsdoc `@see` link, but the issue also affects `[markdown style links](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/11413)`

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.5.0-insider (d2c04e3789757413ae1ebfda9d88896686b6d006, 2016-09-01T06:11:55.766Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-36-generic, Ubuntu 16.04

I got this message when updating this morning 

> A version mismatch between the globally installed tsc compiler (1.5.3) and VS Code's language service (1.8.10) has been detected. This might result in inconsistent compile errors.

I clicked more information and it did nothing. No errors in console.

data.title: Blank lines in Hovers are removed
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5 (Insiders)
- OS Version: Windows 10

This was previously raised and fixed (#10311) in Insiders, but in the last few days it appears to have come back.

Here's the text I'm sending (note: I believe list item spacing is another known issue, so ignore those):

``` text
_italic_ **bold**.

And some \`inline code\`.
```

Here's a screenshot from Insiders last week (good) vs Insiders yesterday (same as Stable)

![Hover spacing](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1078012/18178855/f04a997e-7077-11e6-959a-2e7412d3269c.png)

data.title: F8 widget steals focus from document on every key press
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5 (Insiders)
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Press F8 to open the diagnostics widget
2. Click in the document and try to make some changes

The first key press in the document works, but then focus seems to move to the widget(?) and the subsequent keypresses do not update the document. This makes it really hard to fix the thing the popup is telling you about as you have to put focus back in the editor for every key press (or close the F8 widget).

data.title: F8 widget text doesn't update if diagnostics change while the window is open
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5 (Insiders)
- OS Version: Windows 10

If you edit the doc while the F8 widget is open and that causes diagnostics to update, the widget text doesn't update.

Here you can see I change the name of the function and the diagnostic (bottom) is updated, but the widget still shows the old text.

![Code fix update](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1078012/18052295/6c316d12-6df1-11e6-834b-cdb80f166652.gif)

data.title: Feature Request: Add Current Token to Keybinding Context
data.body:
This is just a hack, so, I don't intent to really have this merged, but I'd like to submit this as a general feature request.

I would like to be able to set custom breakpoints on specific tokens.

This request is related to a previously created more general issue: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/10447

The attached hack essentially captures the current token at the cursor position and exposes it in the keybinding context. 

> BTW: I guess there is a lot of history involved why this is a keybinding thing, but it did not help me to understand that this is also relevant for context menus and other stuff. I was rather confused by the terminology.

I use this specifically to add the following context menu items on the `<-:` tokens, which represent asynchronous message sends in my language.

![Screenshot showing context menu items specific to a token](https://pbs.twimg.com/media/CrSDnbzXEAAR5LV.png)

data.title: Light bulp still visible behind the F8 window
data.body:
From verifying https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/11022:
- Have a css file 

``` css
.aria-container {
    left1:-999em;
}
```
- set the cursor at the end of the line where the error is
- press F8
- set the cursor to the error
  ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6461412/18173442/e11c66e8-7069-11e6-8fd7-9bea87210472.png)

data.title: Add an API to access the problems view
data.body:
I'm looking for a way to show the problems view in an extension. There's the `workbench.actions.view.problems` command, but since it's a toggle, I would also need a way to check if the view is currently opened or not, which does not seem to exist.

The API should probably at least support:
- showing
- hiding
- checking the current visibility of
- clearing 

the problems view.
